description: Understand the role of weird servers in the request/response cycle: HTTP, Virtual Hosts, and Proxies.

slides.title: What is a Web Server?
slides.content:
# The Waiter ü§µ

Software that listens for requests (usually HTTP) and returns content (HTML, JSON, Images).

Examples: Nginx, Apache, IIS.

It sits between the Internet and your Application Code (Node/Python/PHP).

slides.title: Static vs Dynamic
slides.content:
# Serving Content üì¶

- **Static:** Files that don't change (Images, CSS, simple HTML). Web servers are extremely fast at this.
- **Dynamic:** Content generated on the fly by code (PHP, Python). The web server passes the request to the App Server.

slides.title: HTTP / HTTPS
slides.content:
# The Protocol üåê

Web servers speak HTTP.

- **Port 80:** HTTP (Unencrypted).
- **Port 443:** HTTPS (Encrypted via TLS/SSL).

The Web Server handles the SSL termination (decrypting the traffic) so your app doesn't have to.

slides.title: Virtual Hosts
slides.content:
# Many Sites, One Server üè¢

A single server can host multiple websites.

It checks the `Host` header in the request.

- request to `siteA.com` -> serves `/var/www/siteA`
- request to `siteB.com` -> serves `/var/www/siteB`

slides.title: Port Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: Which default TCP port is used for secure HTTPS traffic?

slides.title: Reverse Proxy
slides.content:
# The Middleman üõ°Ô∏è

Sit in front of your app servers.

Client -> Nginx (Reverse Proxy) -> Node.js App

Why?
- Security (Hide backend IP).
- Load Balancing.
- SSL Termination.
- Caching.

slides.title: Caching
slides.content:
# Speed ‚ö°

Web servers can cache responses.

If User A asks for `logo.png`, the server keeps a copy in memory. When User B asks for it, the server returns it instantly without reading the disk.

slides.title: Load Balancing
slides.content:
# Traffic Distribution ‚öñÔ∏è

Spreading requests across multiple backend servers.

Client -> Web Server -> [App 1, App 2, App 3]

Ensures no single app instance gets overwhelmed.

slides.title: Forward Proxy
slides.content:
# The Outbound Broker üì§

- **Reverse Proxy:** Protects Servers (Client doesn't know which server).
- **Forward Proxy:** Protects Clients (Server doesn't know which client/IP). Used in corporate networks (VPNs).

slides.title: Status Codes
slides.content:
# The Language of Response üó£Ô∏è

The Web Server handles many codes automatically:

- **404:** File not found.
- **403:** Permission denied (file permissions).
- **500:** The underlying app crashed.
- **301:** Redirect.

slides.title: Proxy Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: What type of proxy sits in front of backend servers to provide load balancing and security?

slides.title: Code Example
Summary
slides.content:
# Recap: Web Servers üéì

The Gatekeepers.

- **Listen:** Port 80/443.
- **Serve:** Static files FAST.
- **Proxy:** Route dynamic requests to apps.
- **Virtual Hosts:** Multiple sites per server.
- **Cache:** Improve performance.
